revised_title: Sensory Cilia and Neuromuscular Junctions in Ctenophore Independent Effector Organ
tldr: The article investigates the non-motile sensory cilia and neuromuscular junctions in the ctenophore Leucothea multicornis. The sensory cilia act as receptors for water displacement and detect nearby vibrations. The fingers of Leucothea, which are independent effector organs, respond to these vibrations by extending or retracting. The study provides insights into the organization of the nerve net and the specificity of connections between sensory organs and muscle fibers.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Neurobiology and Sensory Systems
